abstract.para: This document defines version 1.0 of JLIFF, the JSON Localization Interchange Fragment Format, based on the XLIFF 2 Object Model that has been in turn based on the XLIFF 2 Family of Standards. The purpose of JLIFF is to provide standard JSON serialization methods for all XLIFF OM objects, their relationships, and data models, so that Localization tools can exchange translation and localization task data in an interoperable way.

Same as [JSON] (its parent etiquette), JLIFF concentrates on real time exchange scenarios. Thanks to the fact that JLIFF and XLIFF (the original XML serialization) share the same Object Model [LIOM], implementers of both formats can rely on and benefit from the semantic and behavioral match between those two interchange formats.

Since JLIFF primarily targets real time API exchanges, it is capable of expressing different levels of fragments corresponding to various structural parts of the XLIFF OM and possibly related XLIFF Documents.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: JSON Localization Interchange Fragment Format (JLIFF), a serialization of the LIOM (Localization Interchange Object Model), which is the XLIFF 2 Object Model, has been designed by a group of multilingual content publishers, software providers, localization service providers, localization tools providers, and researchers. It is intended to give any multilingual content owner a reliable and interoperable JSON serialization of the said object and data model. XLIFF 2 has been providing a reliable XML based interchange file format understood by any localization provider, using any conformant localization tool. The primary focus of this JSON serialization specification of the shared Object Model is to ensure lossless Interchange between JSON and XML pipelines, or indeed other pipelines serialized in other ways, as long as they are based on the same underlying Object Model. While the primary focus is on lossless Interchange, toolmakers, service providers, and content owners are encouraged to stick to the shared Object Model [LIOM] also while designing their internal processing and messaging formats, as this will make the mapping to the standardized Interchange format serializations of this Object Model, such as JLIFF or XLIFF, so much easier.

All text is normative unless otherwise labeled. The following common methods are used for labeling portions of this specification as informative and hence non-normative:
Appendices and sections marked as "(Informative)" or "Non-Normative" in title, Notes (sections with the "Note" title), Warnings (sections with the "Warning" title), Examples (mainly example code listings, tree diagrams, but also any inline examples or illustrative exemplary lists in otherwise normative text), Schema and other validation artifacts listings (the corresponding artifacts are normative, not their listings).

section.title: Key words
section.para: The key words must, must not, required, shall, shall not, should, should not, recommended, may, and optional are to be interpreted as described in .

listitem.para: any application or tool that generates (creates), reads, edits, writes, processes, stores, renders or otherwise handles JLIFF Instances.
Agent is the most general application conformance target that subsumes all other specialized user agents disregarding whether they are defined in this specification or not.
the process of associating metadata and resources with the Extracted JLIFF payload
Enriching may happen at the time of Extraction.

note.para: Extractor knowledge of the native format is not assumed while Enriching.

listitem.para: any Agent that performs the Enriching process

the process of encoding localizable content from a native content or User Interface format as JLIFF Instances, so that localizable parts of the content in the source language are available for Translation into the target language along with the necessary context information
any Agent that performs the Extraction process

the process of importing JLIFF payload back to the originating native format, based on the full knowledge of the Extraction mechanism, so that the localized content or User Interface strings replace the source language in the native format
an Agent that performs the Merge process

warning.para: Unless specified otherwise, any Merger is deemed to have the same knowledge of the native format as the Extractor throughout the specification.
Mergers independent of Extractors can succeed, but it is out of scope of this specification to specify interoperability for Merging back without the full Extractor knowledge of the native format.

listitem.para: the process of changing core and module based structural and inline objects that were previously created by other Writers
JLIFF objects may be Modified and Enriched at the same time.

note.para: Extractor or Enricher knowledge of the native format is not assumed while Modifying.

listitem.para: an Agent that performs the Modification process
a rendering of the meaning of the source text, expressed in the target language
an Agent that creates, generates, or otherwise writes JLIFF Instances for whatever purpose, including but not limited to Extractor, Modifier, and Enricher Agents.

note.para: Since JLIFF is intended as an exchange format rather than a processing format, many applications will need to generate JLIFF Instances from their internal processing formats, even in cases when they are processing JLIFF Instances created by another Extractor.

listitem.para: The core of JLIFF Version 1.0 consists of the minimum set of JSON objects, properties, and values required to (a) prepare a JLIFF Instance that contains text Extracted from one or more files for localization, (b) allow it to be completed with the Translation of the Extracted text, and (c) allow the generation of Translated versions of the original document.
The namespace that corresponds to the core subset of JLIFF Version 1.0 is "urn:oasis:names:tc:xliff:document:2.0".

note.para: Vanilla JSON is not capable of expressing namespaces. Nevertheless, JLIFF adopts two prefix conventions that allow for representing LIOM and XLIFF namespaces to be able to make use of LIOM modularity.
JLIFF Core object or property names are not prefixed either in JLIFF Instances or in the JLIFF JSON Schema.

JLIFF Version 1.0 contains prose and JSON schema specifications of JLIFF 2.0 and JLIFF 2.1. These two serializations share JLIFF Core 2.0 that maps one-to-one to XLIFF Core 2.0 that is shared between XLIFF Version 2.1 and XLIFF Version 2.0

Two different schema instances are provided, JLIFF 2.1 and JLIFF 2.0. The prose specifications contains conditional provisions for JLIFF serialization 2.1 and JLIFF serialization 2.0 in this document.

listitem.para: A module is an optional set of JSON objects and properties that stores information about a process applied to a JLIFF Instance and the data incorporated into the instance as result of that process.

note.para: Each official module defined for JLIFF Vesrion 1.0 has its grammar defined in a JSON Schema integrated with the core JSON schema. Two different schema instances are provided, JLIFF serialization 2.1 and JLIFF serialization 2.0.

listitem.para: All JLIFF-defined objects and properties are specified in this document. The extent of JLIFF-defined is different for the JLIFF serialization 2.1 and JLIFF serialization 2.0. This corresponds to the lists of namespaces used normatively in either of the serializations stated in this specification.
JLIFF Instance is a conforming JSON text according to [ECMA-JSON] Clause 2 that validates against the schema for JLIFF serialization 2.1 or JLIFF serialization 2.0.

listitem.para: JLIFF is a JSON application, therefore conformant JLIFF Instances must be well formed and valid JSON files according to [ECMA-JSON] Clause 2.
Conformant JLIFF Instances must be valid instances of one of the official Core JLIFF Schemas that are parts of this multipart Work Product,
http://docs.oasis-open.org/xliff-omos/jliff/v1.0/wd01/schemas/jliff-schema-2.1.json, for the JLIFF serialization 2.1.
http://docs.oasis-open.org/xliff-omos/jliff/v1.0/wd01/schemas/jliff-schema-2.0.json, for the JLIFF serialization 2.0.

As not all aspects of the JLIFF specification can be expressed in terms of JSON Schemas, conformant JLIFF Instances must also comply with all relevant objects and properties definitions, normative usage descriptions, and Constraints specified in this specification document.
JLIFF Instances may contain custom extensions, as defined in the Extension Mechanisms section.
JLIFF Writers must create conformant JLIFF Instances to be considered JLIFF compliant.

Agents processing conformant JLIFF Instances that contain custom extensions are not required to understand and process non-JLIFF objects or properties. However, conformant applications should preserve existing custom extensions when processing conformant JLIFF Instances, provided that the objects or properties that contain custom extensions are not removed according to JLIIFF Processing Requirements or the extension's own processing requirements.
All Agents must comply with Processing Requirements for otherwise unspecified Agents or without a specifically set target Agent.

Specialized Agents defined in this specification - this is Extractor, Merger, Writer, Modifier, and Enricher Agents - must comply with the Processing Requirements targeting their specifically defined type of Agent on top of Processing Requirements targeting all Agents as per point c. above.

JLIFF is a format explicitly designed for exchanging data among various Agents. Thus, a conformant JLIFF application must be able to accept JLIFF Instances it had written after those JLIFF Instances were Modified or Enriched by a different application, provided that:
The processed files are conformant JLIFF Instances,
in a state compliant with all relevant Processing Requirements.
Conformant applications are required to support both serializations defined in this specifcation.
No previous versions of JLIFF exist.

note.para: JLIFF Instances conformant to this specification are suitable for exchange of data with XLIFF 2 Documents based processes. Normative Appendix C [insert coss reference once created] provides requirements for and guidance on roundtripping XLIFF 2 data using JLIFF, i.e. how to import XLIFF 2 data to JLIFF and how to export JLIFF data to XLIFF 2.0 or XLIFF 2.1.

section.title: Fragment Identification
section.para: This specification defines how Agents must interpret the fragment identifiers in IRIs pointing to JLIFF Instances.

note.para: Since JLIFF uses the same fragid mechanism as XLIFF. XLIFF and JLIFF identifiers will work interchangeably across the JLIFF and XLIFF media types.
Note that some identifiers can change during the localization process. For example on resegmentation or when regrouping or not data objects depending on how tools treat identical original data.

listitem.para: A fragment identifier must match the following format:
There must not be two identical prefixes in the expression.
When used, the following selectors must be declared in this order: file selector, group selector and unit selector.
The selectors for modules or extensions, <note>, <segment> or <ignorable> or source inline elements, target inline elements and <data> have the following constraints:
Only one of them may be used in the expression.
The one used must be the last selector of the expression.

warning.para: Please note that due to the above Constraints, referencing fragments using third party namespaces within Modules or extensions (including but not limited to XLIFF Core or the Metadata Module) is not possible. This is to restrict the complexity of the fragment identification mechanism, as it would otherwise have potentially unlimited depth.

listitem.para: The prefix f indicates an anonymous file object id and the value of that id is unique among all anonymous file object required id property values within the enclosing anonymous jliff object.

The prefix g indicates an anonymous subitem object "kind" : "group" id and the value of that id is unique among all anonymous subitem object "kind" : "group" id attribute values within the enclosing anonymous file object or anonymous jliff object.

The prefix u indicates an anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit" id and the value of that id is unique among all anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit" id property values within the enclosing anonymous file object or anonymous jliff object.
The prefix n indicates a anonymous note object id and the value of that id is unique among all anonymous note object id property values within the same anonymous notes array.

The prefix d indicates a <data> id and the value of that id is unique among all <data> id attribute values within the enclosing <unit> element. [pending modification of descriptions for data and original data objects/arrays]

The prefix t indicates an id for an inline object contained in an anonymous target property array and the value of that id is unique within the enclosing anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit" with the exception of the matching inline objects contained in its sibling anonymous source property array.

No prefix indicates an id for an anonymous subunit item "kind" : "segment" or an anonymous subunit object "kind" : "ignorable" or an inline element in the anonymous source property array and the value of that id is unique within the enclosing anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit" with the exception of the matching inline objects contained its sibling anonymous target property array.

section.title: Selectors for Modules and Extensions
section.para: A selector for a module or an extension uses a registered prefix and the value of that id is unique within the immediate enclosing anonymous file object, anonymous subitem object "kind" : "group", or anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit".

listitem.para: The prefix of a module or an extension must be an NMTOKEN longer than 1 character and must be defined in the module or extension specification.
The prefix of a module or an extension must be registered with the XLIFF TC.
A given module or extension namespace URI must be associated with a single prefix.
A prefix may be associated with more than one namespace URI (to allow for example different versions of a given module or extension to use the same prefix).

section.para: See also the constraints related to how IDs need to be specified in extensions (which applies for modules as well).

section.title: Relative References
section.para: Fragment identifiers that do not start with a character / (U+002F) are relative to their location in the document, or to the document being processed.
Any unit, group or file selector missing to resolve the relative reference is obtained from the immediate enclosing unit, group or file object.

section.title: Examples
section.para: Given the following JLIFF Instance:
section.programlisting: { "jliff": "2.1", "srcLang": "en-US", "trgLang": "fr-FR", "files": [ { "id": "f1", "kind": "file", "notes": [ { "id": "n1", "text": "note for file." } ], "subfiles": [ { "canResegment": "no", "id": "u1", "kind": "unit", "notes": [ { "id": "n1", "text": "note for unit" } ], "subunits": [ { "id": "s1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "sc" }, { "text": "Hello " }, { "id": "m1", "kind": "sm", "type": "term" }, { "text": "World" }, { "kind": "em", "startRef": "m1" }, { "text": "!" }, { "kind": "ec", "startRef": "1" } ], "target": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "sc" }, { "text": "Bonjour le " }, { "id": "m1", "kind": "sm", "type": "term" }, { "text": "Monde" }, { "kind": "em", "startRef": "m1" }, { "text": "!" }, { "kind": "ec", "startRef": "1" } ] } ] } ] } ] }
section.para: You can have the following fragment identifiers:

listitem.para: #f=f1/u=u1/1 refers to the anonymous object { "id": "1", "kind": "sc" } of the source content of the anonymous object { "id": "u1", "kind": "unit", … }.
#f=f1/u=u1/t=1 refers to the anonymous object { "id": "1", "kind": "sc" } of the target content of the anonymous object { "id": "u1", "kind": "unit", … }.
#f=f1/n=n1 refers to the anonymous note object with a required "text" property { "id": "n1", "text": "note for file." } of the anonymous object { "id": "f1", "kind": "file", … }.
#f=f1/u=u1/n=n1 refers to the anonymous note object with a required "text" property { "id": "n1", "text": "note for unit." } of the anonymous object { "id": "u1", "kind": "unit", … }.
#f=f1/u=u1/s1 refers to the anonymous subunit object { "id": "s1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ … ], "target": [ … ]} of the anonymous object { "id": "u1", "kind": "unit", … }.

Assuming the extension defined by the namespace URI myNamespaceURI has registered the prefix myprefix, the expression #f=f1/u=u1/myprefix=x1 refers to the element <my:element id="x1"> of the element <unit id="u1">. [JLIFF example doesn't convert the extension]

section.title: The Core Specification
section.para: JLIFF is a bilingual JSON interchange format designed to contain text that needs Translation, its corresponding translations, and auxiliary data that makes the Translation process possible.
At creation time, a JLIFF Instance may contain only text in the source language. Translations expressed in the target language may be added at a later time.
JLIFF postulates several possible root objects. The highest level object corresponds to LIF.
The LIFF object corresponds to the root element of an XLIFF Document, which is <xliff>.

WORK IN PROGRESS!!! THE FOLLOWING PARTS OF THE SPECIFICATION NEED RESTATED IN AN XML INDEPENDENT WAY It contains a collection of <file> elements. Typically, each <file> element contains a set of <unit> elements that contain the text to be translated in the <source> child of one or more <segment> elements. Translations are stored in the <target> child of each <segment> element.

listitem.para: An Agent processing a valid XLIFF Document that contains XLIFF-defined elements and attributes that it cannot handle must preserve those elements and attributes.
An Agent processing a valid XLIFF Document that contains custom elements and attributes that it cannot handle should preserve those elements and attributes.

section.title: Roundtripping XLIFF <cp/>
section.para: XLIFF <cp> represents a Unicode character that is invalid in XML.

simplelist.member: JLIFF doesn't have an equivalent to XLIFF <cp>

section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <segment> <source>Ctrl+C=<cp hex="0003"/></source> </segment> </unit>
section.para: Equivalent of the above example in JLIFF:

The example above shows a character U+0003 (Control C) as it has to be represented in JLIFF. JSON imposes no restrictions on character content. Special characters must be escaped in JSON. Special characters are " and \ and the control characters according to the JSON standard. As the character ETX is legal in JSON, the <cp hex="0003"> becomes the literal of "^C" or "ETX" in the JLIFF serialization. in case of mixed XLIFF and JLIFF pipelines the conversion mechanism needs to be able to "cp-encode" XML illegal characters in LIFF on the fly or vice versa to replace the "cp-encoded" XLIFF representations with their literal equivalents in JLIFF.

listitem.para: JLIFF Writers receiving JLIFF <cp> must replace the code with the corresponding literal character given by the XLIFF hex attribute.

XLIFF Writers receiving illegal XML characters (Unicode characters with hexadecimal codes from 0000 to 10FFFF) must replace each XML illegal character with the XLIFF <cp> element using the corresponding hex attribute.
XLIFF Writers must not encode valid XML characters of the content using <cp>.

section.title: JLIFF Core Object Properties
section.para: This section lists all the various properties used in JLIFF core objects.

The properties defined in JLIFF Version 1.0 are: appliesTo, canCopy, canDelete, canOverlap, canReorder, canResegment, category, copyOf, dataRef, dir, disp, equiv, hex, href, id, isolated, kind, name, order, original, priority, ref, srcDir, srcLang, startRef, state, subFlows,
subState, subType, trgLang, translate, trgDir, type, value and version.

section.title: appliesTo
section.para: Comment target - indicates the property to what the content of the note applies.
Type: string.
Value description: "source" or "target".
Default value: undefined.
Used in: note.

section.title: canCopy
section.para: Replication editing hint - indicates whether or not the inline code can be copied.
Type: string.
Value description: "yes" if the code can be copied, "no" if the code is not intended to be copied.
Default value: "yes".
Used in: sc, ec, ph.

section.title: canDelete
section.para: Deletion editing hint - indicates whether or not the inline code can be deleted.
Type: string.
Value description: "yes" if the code can be deleted, "no" if the code is not allowed to be deleted.
Default value: "yes".
Used in: sc, ec, ph.

section.title: canOverlap
section.para: Code can overlap - indicates whether or not the spanning code where this string is used can enclose partial spanning codes (i.e. a start code without its corresponding end code, or an end code without its corresponding start code).
Type: string.
Value description: "yes" or "no".
Default value: "yes".
Used in: sc and ec
section.programlisting:
<unit id="1"> <originalData> <data id="1">\i1 </data> <data id="2">\i0 </data> <data id="3">{\b </data> <data id="4">}</data> </originalData> <segment> <source><pc id="1" dataRefStart="3" dataRefEnd="4" canOverlap="no"> Bold, <sc id="2" dataRef="1" canOverlap="yes"/>both</pc>, italics<ec startRef="2" dataRef="2"/></source> </segment> </unit>
{ "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "originalData": { "1": "\\i1 ", "2": "\\i0 ", "3": "{\\b ", "4": "}" }, "subunits": [ { "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "sc", "dataRef": "3", "canOverlap": "no" }, { "text": "Bold, " }, { "id": "2", "kind": "sc", "dataRef": "1", "canOverlap": "yes" }, { "text": "both" }, { "kind": "ec", "startRef": "1", "dataRef": "4" }, { "text": ", italics" }, { "kind": "ec", "startRef": "2", "dataRef": "2" } ] } ] }

section.title: canReorder
section.para: Re-ordering editing hint - indicates whether or not the inline code can be re-ordered. See Editing Hints section for more details.
Type: string.
Value description: "yes" in case the code can be re-ordered, "firstNo" when the code is the first element of a sequence that cannot be re-ordered, "no" when it is another element of such a sequence.
Default value: "yes".
Used in: sc, ec, ph.

section.title: canResegment
section.para: Can resegment - indicates whether or not the source text in the scope of the given canResegment flag can be reorganized into a different structure of segment objects within the same parent unit.
Type: string.
Value description: "yes" or "no".
Default value: default values for this string depend on the object in which the "canResegment" property is used:

listitem.para: When used in file:
The value "yes".
When the "canResegment" property is used in any other object:
The value of the canResegment string of its parent object.

section.para: Used in: file group unit, and segment.

section.title: category
section.para: Category - provides a way to categorize notes.
Type: string.
Value description: text.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: note.

section.title: copyOf
section.para: Reference to base code - holds the id of the base code of a copied code.
Type: string.
Value description: NMTOKEN. The id value of the base code of which this code is a copy.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: ph, sc, ec.
section.programlisting:
<unit id="1"> <segment> <source>Äter <pc id="1">katter möss</pc>?</source> <target>Do <pc id="1">cats</pc> eat <pc id="2" copyOf="1"> mice</pc>? </target> </segment> </unit>
{ "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "subunits": [ { "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Äter" }, { "id": "1", "kind": "sc" }, { "text", "katter möss" }, { "id": "2", "kind": "ec", "startRef": "1" }, { "text": "?" } ], "target": [ { "text": "Do " }, { "id": "1", "kind": "sc" }, { "text": "cats" }, { "kind": "ec", "startRef": "1" }, { "text": " eat " }, { "id": "2", "kind": "sc", "copyOf": "1" }, { "text": "mice" }, { "kind": "ec", "startRef": "2" }, { "text": "?" } ] } ] }

section.title: dataRef property
section.para: Original data reference - holds the NMTOKEN key to the original data string contained in the unit level "originalData" vocabulary object that contains the original data for a given inline code.
Type: string.
Value description: NMTOKEN: a string matching the pattern [-._:A-Za-z0-9]+.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: ph, sc, ec.

listitem.para: The dataRef property value must be one of the NMTOKEN key properties of the "originalData" object in the same anonymous unit object, to which it points to.

Agents processing the "dataref" property pointers must also lookup the NMTOKEN keys in the corresponding originalDataDir vocabulary object, if and only if such an object exists within the same same anonymous unit object.

section.programlisting:
<unit id="1"> <originalData> <data id="d1">{0}</data> <data id="d2">{1}</data> </originalData> <segment> <source>Error in '<ph id="1" dataRef="d1"/>' and '<ph id="2" dataRef="d2"/>'.</source> <target>Erreur dans '<ph id="1" dataRef="d1"/>' et '<ph id="1" dataRef="d1"/>'.</target> </segment> </unit>
{ "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "originalData": { "d1": "{0}", "d2" : "{1}" }, "subunits": [ { "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Error in '" }, { "id": "1", "kind": "ph", "dataRef": "d1"}, { "text" : "' and '"}, { "id": "2", "kind": "ph", "dataRef": "d2"}, { "text": "'." } ] } ] }
section.para: The example above shows two ph objects that have their original data stored outside the content, in an "originaldata" vocabulary object.

section.title: dir
section.para: Directionality - indicates the directionality of content.
Type: string.
Value description: "ltr" (Left-To-Right), "rtl" (Right-To-Left), or "auto" (determined heuristically, based on the first strong directional character in scope, see [UAX #9]).
Default value: default values for this attribute depend on the element in which it is used:

listitem.para: When used in a <pc>, sc, or ec object that has a source object as its parent:
The value of the srcDir string of the unit object, in which the "dir" properties are located.
When used in a <pc>, sc, or ec object that has a target object as its parent:
The value of the trgDir string of the unit object, in which the "dir" properties are located.
When used in a <pc>, <sc>, or <ec> object that has a <pc> element as its parent:
The value of the dir attribute of the parent <pc> element.
When used in <data>:
The value "auto".

section.para:
Used in:
<data>, pc, sc, and ec.

section.title: disp
section.para: Display text - holds an alternative user-friendly display representation of the original data of the inline code.
Type: string.
Value description: text.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: ph, sc, ec.
section.programlisting:
<unit id="1"> <originalData> <data id="d1">{1}</data> </originalData> <segment> <source>Welcome back <ph id="1" disp="[UserName]" dataRef="d1"/>! </source> </segment> </unit>
{ "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "originalData": { "d1": "{1}" }, "subunits": [ { "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Welcome back " }, { "id": "1", "kind": "ph", "disp": "[UserName]", "dataRef": "d1" }, { "text": "!" } ] } ] }

note.para: To provide a plain text equivalent of the code, use the equiv property.

section.title: equiv
section.para: Equivalent text - holds a plain text representation of the original data of the inline code that can be used when generating a plain text representation of the content.
Type: string.
Value description: text.
Default value: an empty string "".
Used in: ph, sc, ec.
section.programlisting:
<unit id="1">
  <originalData>
    <data id="d1">&</data>
  </originalData>
  <segment>
    <source>Open <ph id="1" equiv="" dataRef="d1"/>File</source>
  </segment>
</unit>


  {
    "id": "1",
    "kind": "unit",
    "originalData": { "d1": "&" },
    "subunits": [
      {
        "kind": "segment",
        "source": [
          { "text": "Open " },
          { "id": "1", "kind": "ph", "equiv": "", "dataRef": "d1" },
          { "text": "File" }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
section.para: In this example the equiv property of the ph object is used to indicate that the original data of the code can be ignored in the text representation of the string. This could, for instance, help a spell-checker tool to process the content as "Open File".

note.para: To provide a user-friendly representation, use the disp property.

section.title: hex TO BE DELETED, not used in JLIFF
section.para: Hexadecimal code point - holds the value of a Unicode code point that is invalid in XML.

Value description: A canonical representation of the hexBinary [XML Schema Datatypes] data type: Two hexadecimal digits to represent each octet of the Unicode code point. The allowed values are any of the values representing code points invalid in XML, between hexadecimal 0000 and 10FFFF (both included).
Default value: undefined
Used in: <cp>.
The example above shows a character U+001A and a character U+0003 as they have to be represented in XLIFF.

section.title: href
section.para: ref - a pointer to the location of an external skeleton file pertaining to the enclosing file object.
Type: string.
Value description: IRI.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: skeleton.

section.title: id
section.para: Identifier - a character string used to identify an element.
Type: string.
Value description: NMTOKEN: a string matching the pattern [-._:A-Za-z0-9]+. The scope of the values for this string depends on the object in which the "id" property is used.

listitem.para: When used in a file object:
The value of the "id" property strings must be unique among all file id string values within the enclosing jliff object.
When used in group object:
The value of the "id" property strings must be unique among all group id string values within the enclosing file object.
When used in unit object:
The value of the "id" property strings must be unique among all unit id string values within the enclosing file object.
When used in note objects:
The value of the "id" property strings must be unique among all note id string values within the immediate enclosing file, group, or unit object.
When used in segment, ignorable, <mrk>, sm, <pc>, sc, ec, or ph elements:

The inline elements enclosed by a target object must use the duplicate id string values of their corresponding inline elements enclosed within the sibling source object if and only if those corresponding elements exist.
Except for the above exception, the value must be unique among all of the above within the enclosing unit object.

note.para: All of the above defined uniqueness scopes ignore Module and Extension data. It would be impossible to impose those uniqueness requirements onto Module or Extension data. As Core only Modifiers could inadvertently cause conflicts with Modules or Extensions based data they cannot access. Modules and Extensions reusing Core need to specify their own uniqueness scopes for the xlf:id. In general, Modules and Extensions are advised to mimic the Core uniqueness requirement within their specific wrapper elements enclosing the reused Core elements or attributes, yet Module or Extensions are free to set wider uniqueness scopes if it makes business sense for processing.

section.para: Default value: undefined.
Used in: file, group, unit, note, segment, ignorable, <data>, sc, ec, ph, <pc>, <mrk> and sm.

section.title: isolated
section.para: Orphan code flag - indicates if the start or end marker of a spanning inline code is not in the same unit as its corresponding end or start code.
Type: string.
Value description: "yes" if this start or end code is not in the same unit as its corresponding end or start code, "no" if both codes are in the same unit.
Default value: "no".
Used in: sc, ec.
section.programlisting:
<file id="f2" xmlns:abc="urn:abc">
  <unit id="1">
    <mtc:matches>
      <mtc:match id="tc01" ref="seg2">
        <source><sc id="1" isolated="yes"/>Warning:</source>
        <target><sc id="1" isolated="yes"/>Attention :</target>
      </mtc:match>
    </mtc:matches>
    <segment id="seg2">
      <source><pc id="1">Warning: File not found.</pc></source>
    </segment>
  </unit>
</file>


    {
      "id": "f2",
      "subfiles": [
        {
          "id": "1",
          "kind": "unit",
          "mtc_matches": [
            {
              "mtc_id": "tc01",
              "mtc_ref": "seg2",
              "source": [
                { "id": "1", "kind": "sc", "isolated": "yes" },
                { "text": "Warning:" }
              ],
              "target": [
                { "id": "1", "kind": "sc", "isolated": "yes" },
                { "text": "Attention :" }
              ]
            }
          ],
          "subunits": [
            {
              "id": "seg2",
              "kind": "segment",
              "source": [
                { "id": "1", "kind": "sc" },
                { "text": "Warning: File not found." },
                { "kind": "ec", "startRef": "1" }
              ]
            }
          ]
        }
      ]
    }
section.para: In the example above the sc objects have their isolated strings of their "isolated" property set to "yes" because they do not have their corresponding ec objects.

section.title: kind TO DO
section.para: Indicates the type of an object.
Type: string.
Default value: none.

section.title: name
section.para: Resource name - the original identifier of the resource corresponding to the Extracted unit or group.
For example: the key in the key/value pair in a Java properties file, the ID of a string in a Windows string table, the index value of an entry in a database table, etc.
Type: string.
Value description: text.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: unit and group.

section.title: "targetOrder" property
section.para: target order - indicates the order, in which to compose the target content parts.
Type: number.
Value description: positive integer.
Default value: implicit, see below

When targetOrder is not explicitly set, the order of the target content is the natural one, i.e. it corresponds to its sibling source property conetnt, i.e. it is not being moved anywhere when composing the target content of the enclosing anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit" and the implicit targetOrder value the ordinal number (expressed as a positive integer) of that position within the anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit".
Used in: anonymous subunit object "kind" : "segment" and anonymous subunit object "kind" : "ignorable".

listitem.para: The value of the targetOrder property must be unique within the enclosing anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit".

The value of each of the targetOrder attributes used within a anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit" must not be higher than N, where N is the number of all current anonymous subunit objects "kind" : "segment" and anonymous subunit objects "kind" : "ignorable".

section.para: See the Segments Order section for the normative usage description.

section.title: original
section.para: Original file - a pointer to the location of the original document from which the content of the enclosing file object is extracted.
Type: string.
Value description: IRI.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: file.

section.title: priority
section.para: Priority - provides a way to prioritize notes.
Type: number.
Value description: integer between 1 and 10, inclusive.
Default value: 1.
Used in: note.

note.para: Please note that 1 is the highest priority that can be interpreted as an alert, e.g. an [ITS] Localization Note of the type alert. The best practice is to use only one alert per an annotated note, and the full scale of 2-10 can be used for prioritizing notes of lesser importance than the alert.

section.title: state
section.para: State - indicates the state of the translation of a segment.
Type: string.
Value description: the value must be set to one of the following values:

simplelist.member: "initial" - indicates the segment is in its initial state.
"translated" - indicates the segment has been translated.
"reviewed" - indicates the segment has been reviewed.
"final" - indicates the segment is finalized and ready to be used.

section.para: The 4 defined states constitute a simple linear state machine that advances in the above given order. No particular workflow or process is prescribed, except that the three states more advanced than the default initial assume the existence of a Translation within the segment. One can further specify the state of the Translation using the subState attribute.
Default value: "initial".

listitem.para: Writers must not set the state attribute values to other than the default "initial" if and only if the segment object where the property is set doesn't have the target child.
Writers updating the property state must also update or delete subState.

note.para: state is an optional property of segments with a default value and segmentation can change as the JLIFF roundtrip progresses, hence implementers don't have to make explicit use of the property. However setting of the property is advantageous if a workflow needs to make use of Advanced Validation methods.

section.title: subFlows
section.para: Sub-flows list - holds a list of id attributes corresponding to the unit objects that contain the sub-flows for a given inline code.
Type: string.
Value description: A list of NMTOKEN values separated by spaces, where NMTOKEN is a string matching the pattern [-._:A-Za-z0-9]+.Each value corresponds to the id attribute of a unit object.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: ph, sc, ec.
See the example in the Sub-Flows section.

section.title: subState
section.para: subState - indicates a user-defined status for the segment object.
Type: string.
A string value composed of a prefix and a sub-value separated by a character : (U+003A).
The prefix is a string uniquely identifying a collection of values for a specific authority. The sub-value is any string value defined by an authority.
The prefix xlf is reserved for this specification.
Other prefixes and sub-values may be defined by the users.
Default value: undefined.

listitem.para: If the property subState is used, the property state must be explicitly set.
Writers updating the property state must also update or delete subState.

section.title: subType
section.para: subType - indicates the secondary level type of an inline code.
Type: string.
The value is composed of a prefix and a sub-value separated by a character : (U+003A).
The prefix is a string uniquely identifying a collection of sub-values for a specific authority. The sub-value is any string value defined by the authority.
The prefix xlf is reserved for this specification, and the following sub-values are defined:

simplelist.member: xlf:lb - Line break
xlf:pb - Page break
xlf:b - Bold
xlf:i - Italics
xlf:u - Underlined
xlf:var - Variable

section.para: Other prefixes and sub-values may be defined by the users.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: <pc>, sc, ec and ph

listitem.para: If the property subType is used, the property type must be specified as well.
The reserved xlf: prefixed values map onto the type property values as follows:

simplelist.member: For xlf:b, xlf:i, xlf:u, xlf:lb, and xlf:pb, the required value of the type property is "fmt".
For xlf:var, the required value of the type property is "ui".

listitem.para: Modifiers updating the property type must also update or delete subType.

Type: string.

The value "yes".
When used in any other admissible structural element (group or unit):
The value of the translate property of its parent object.

The value "auto".
When used in any other element:
The value of the trgDir attribute of its parent element.

section.title: codeType

Type: string.

"ui" - User interface element
"quote" - Inline quotation (as opposed to a block citation)
"link" - Link (e.g. an <a> element in HTML)

section.title: xml:space [NOT USED]
section.para: White spaces - the xml:space attribute specifies how white spaces (ASCII spaces, tabs and line-breaks) are to be treated.

Value description: default or preserve. The value default signals that an application's default white-space processing modes are acceptable for this element; the value preserve indicates the intent that applications preserve all the white space. This declared intent is considered to apply to all elements within the content of the element where it is specified, unless overridden with another instance of the xml:space attribute. For more information see the section on xml:space in the [XML] specification.
Default value: default values for this attribute depend on the element in which it is used:

listitem.para: When used in <data>:
The value preserve.
When used in <xliff>:
The value default.
When used in any other element:
The value of the xml:space attribute of its parent element.

section.title: CDATA sections
section.para: CDATA sections (<![CDATA[...]]>) are allowed in XLIFF content, but on output they may be changed into normal escaped content.
Note that avoiding CDATA sections is considered a best practice from the internationalization viewpoint [XML I18N BP].

listitem.para: Agents must process CDATA sections.
Writers may preserve the original CDATA sections.

section.title: Inline Content
section.para: The JLIFF inline content defines how to encode the content Extracted from the original source. The content includes the following types of data:

listitem.para: Text -- Textual content.
Inline codes -- Sequences of content that are not linguistic text, such as formatting codes, variable placeholders, etc.
For example: the element <b> in HTML, or the placeholder {0} in a Java string.
Annotations -- Markers that delimit a span of the content and carry or point to information about the specified content.
For example: a flag indicating that a given section of text is not intended for translation, or an annotation indicating that a given expression in the text is a term associated with a definition.

section.para: There are two properties with array values that contain inline objects in JLIFF: the "source" property and "target" property.
In some cases, data directly associated with inline objects may also be stored at the level of the anonymous subitem object of the "kind" : "unit" level in an "originalData" object.

section.title: Text
section.para: The JLIFF anonymous inline "text" object does not prescribe how to represent normal text, besides that the "text" values of the objects must be valid JSON strings.

section.title: Characters invalid in XML
section.para: Because the content represented in XLIFF can be extracted from anywhere, including software resources and other material that can contain control characters, XLIFF needs to be able to represent all Unicode code points [Unicode].
However, XML does not have the capability to represent all Unicode code points [Unicode], and does not provide any official mechanism to escape the forbidden code points.
To remedy this, the inline markup provides the <cp> element.
The syntax and semantic of <cp> in XLIFF are similar to the ones of <cp> in the Unicode Locale Data Markup Language [LDML].

section.title: Inline Codes
section.para: The specification takes into account two types of codes:

listitem.para: An original code is a code that exists in the original document being extracted into JLIFF.
An added code is a code that does not exist in the original document, but has been added to the content at some point after extraction.

section.para: Any code (original or added) belongs to one of the two following categories:

listitem.para:
A standalone code is a code that corresponds to a single position in the content. An example of such code is the
element in HTML.
A spanning code is a code that encloses a section of the content using a start and an end marker. There are two kinds of spanning codes:

Codes that can overlap, that is: they can enclose a non-closing or a non-opening spanning code. Such codes do not have an XML-like behavior. For example the RTF code \b1...\b0 is a spanning code that is allowed to overlap.

Codes that cannot overlap, that is: they cannot enclose a partial spanning code and have an XML-like behavior at the same time. An example of such code is the <emphasis>...</emphasis> element in DocBook.
When the opening or closing marker of a spanning code does not have its corresponding closing or opening marker in the same unit, it is an orphan code.

section.title: Representation of the codes
section.para: Spanning codes present a set of challenges in JLIFF:
First, because the code format of the original data extracted to JLIFF does not need to be XML, spanning codes can overlap.
For example, in the following RTF content, the format markers are in a sequence: start bold, start italics, end bold, end italics. This does not translate into a well-formed mapping.
section.programlisting: Text in \b bold \i and\b0 italics\i0
section.para: Another challenge is the possible effect of segmentation: A spanning code can start in one segment and end in another.

For example, in the following HTML content, the segmentation splits the text independently of the codes so the starting and ending tags of the ... element end up in different parts of the anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit":
section.programlisting: [Sentence one. ][Sentence two.][ ][Sentence three.]
section.para: Finally, a third potential cause of complication is that the start or the end markers of a spanning code can become orphans if their segment is used outside of its original anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit".
For example, an entry with bold text can be broken down into two segments:
section.programlisting: Segment 1 = "Warning found: " Segment 2 = "The file is read-only"
section.para: And later, one of the segments can be re-used outside its original anonymous subitem object "kind" : "unit", for instance as a translation candidate:
section.programlisting: New segment = "Warning found - see log" Fuzzy match = "Warning found: "
section.para: Because of these use cases, the representation of a spanning code cannot always be mapped to a similar spanning element in XLIFF. Since XLIFF defines an equivalence between well formed spanning markup and markup forming spans with start and and end codes, it is not necessary for a non-XML translation roundgtrip format such as JLIFF to mimic the XLIFF capability to represent well formed original markup as wellformed in the translation format.

The only method to encode spanning codes in JLIFF is with start and end codes tied by an id and id reference, disregarding whether the original markup was or wasn't wellformed or whether a well formed representation would be theoretically possible in an XML vocabulary such as XLIFF.
The following table shows examples how different types of code have to represented in JLIFF:

When converting representation between a pair of <sc> and <ec> elements and a <pc> element or vice-versa, Modifiers must map their attributes as shown in the following table:
