section.title: Introduction
section.para: The Size and Length Restriction module provides a mechanism to annotate the XLIFF content with information on storage and general size restrictions.

The restriction framework has support for two distinct types of restrictions; storage size restrictions and general size restriction. The reason for this is that it is often common to have separate restrictions between storage and display / physical representation of data. Since it would be impossible to define all restrictions here a concept of restriction profile is introduced. The profiles for storage size and general size are independent. The information related to restriction profiles are stored in the processing invariant part of the XLIFF file like the <xlf:file>, <xlf:group> and <xlf:unit> elements and contained within elements defined in this module. The information regarding the specific restrictions are stored on the processing invariant parts and on the inline elements as attributes or attributes referencing data in the elements defined in this module. To avoid issues with segmentation no information regarding size restrictions is present on <xlf:segment>, <xlf:source> and <xlf:target> elements. The module defines a namespace for all the elements and attributes it introduces, in the rest of the module specification elements and attributes are in this namespace unless stated otherwise. In other parts of the XLIFF specification the prefix "slr" is used to refer to this module's namespace. For clarity the prefix "xlf" will be used for XLIFF Core elements and attributes. Profile names use the same namespace-like naming convention as user defined values in the XLIFF Core specification. The names should be composed of two components separated by a colon. <authority>:<name>. The authority "xliff" is reserved for profiles defined by the OASIS XLIFF Technical Committee.

section.title: Module Namespace and Validation Artifacts
section.para: The namespace for the Size and Length restriction module is: urn:oasis:names:tc:xliff:sizerestriction:2.0

Schema and Schematron for this module are available at http://docs.oasis-open.org/xliff-omos/jliff/v1.0/wd01/schemas/size_restriction.xsd and http://docs.oasis-open.org/xliff-omos/jliff/v1.0/wd01/schemas/size_restriction.sch.

section.title: Module Fragment Identification Prefix
section.para: The fragment identification prefix for the Size and Length restriction module is: slr

section.title: Module Elements
section.para: The elements defined in the Size and Length restriction module are: <profiles>, <normalization> and <data>.

section.title: Tree Structure
section.para: Legend:

simplelist.member: ? = zero or one

section.programlisting: <profiles> | +---<normalization> ? | +---<other> *

section.title: slr_profiles
section.para: This object selects the restriction profiles to use in the document. If no storage or general profile is specified the default values (empty) of those objects will disable restriction checking in the file.
Type: object

simplelist.member: - Zero or one <normalization> element followed by
- elements from other namespaces, optional
- "slr_normalizatio", a slr_normalization object, optional
- "slr_generalProfile", a slr_generalProfile string, optional
- "slr_storageProfile", a slr_storageProfile string, optional

listitem.para: The following optional JLIFF Extension property is allowed:
"userdata", a userdata object.
No other properties are permitted.
Any overall configuration or settings related to the selected profile must be placed in child objects of this object. DOES THIS MEAN "userdata"?
Data not related to the configuration of the selected profiles must not be placed in this object.

section.title: slr_normalization
section.para: This object is used to hold the properties specifying the normalization form to apply to storage and size restrictions defined in the standard profiles.
Type: object.

simplelist.member: This element is always empty.
- "slr_general", a slr_general string with value "none", "nfc", or "nfd", optional
- "slr_storage", a slr_storage string with value "none", "nfc", or "nfd", optional

listitem.para: If this object is not present no normalization should be performed for the standard profiles.
Other profiles may use this object in its specified form but must not add new extensions to it.

section.title: slr_data
section.para: This object act as a container for data needed by the specified profile to check the part of the JLIFF document that is a sibling or descendant of a sibling of this object. It is not used by the default profiles.
Type: object.

simplelist.member: - elements from other namespaces, optional
- "slr_profile", a profile object, required
- attributes from other namespaces, optional

listitem.para: Third party profiles must place all data in this object instead of using other extension points if the data serves no other purpose in the processing of the document.
Data not used by the specified profile must not be placed in this object.

section.title: Module Attributes
section.para: The attributes defined in the Size and Length restriction module are: storageProfile, generalProfile, storage, general, profile, storageRestriction, sizeRestriction, equivStorage , sizeInfo and sizeInfoRef.

section.title: slr_storageProfile
section.para: This string property specifies, which profile to use while checking storage size restrictions. Empty string means that no restrictions are applied.
Type: string.
Value description: Name of restriction profile to use for storage size restrictions.
Default value: empty string
Used in:slr_profiles.

section.title: slr_generalProfile
section.para: This string property specifies, which profile to use while checking the general size restrictions. Empty string means that no restrictions apply.
Type: string.
Value description: Name of restriction profile to use for general size restrictions.
Default value: empty string.
Used in:slr_profiles.

section.title: slr_storage
section.para: This string property specifies the normalization form to apply for storage size restrictions. Only the normalization forms C and D as specified by the Unicode Consortium are supported, see Unicode Standard Annex #15.
Type: string.
Value description: normalization to apply.

row.entry: No additional normalization should be done, content should be used as represented in the document. It is possible that other Agents have already done some type of normalization when Modifying content. This means that this setting could give different results depending on what Agents are used to perform a specific action on the JLIFF Document.
Normalization Form C must be used
Normalization Form D must be used

section.para: Used in: slr_normalization.

section.title: slr_general
section.para: This string property specifies the normalization to apply for general size restrictions. Only the normalization forms C and D as specified by the Unicode Consortium are supported, see Unicode Standard Annex #15.
Type: string.
Value description: normalization to apply.

row.entry: No additional normalization should be done, content should be used as represented in the document. It is possible that other Agents have already done some type of normalization when Modifying content. This means that this setting could give different results depending on what Agents are used to perform a specific action on the JLIFF Document.
Normalization Form C must be used
Normalization Form D must be used

section.para: Used in:slr_normalization.

section.title: slr_profile
section.para: This string property is used on the slr_data object to indicate what profile the contents of that object apply to.
Type: string.
Value description: Name of a restriction profile.
Default value: undefined.
Used in:slr_data.

section.title: slr_storageRestriction
section.para: This string property specifies the storage restriction to apply to the collection descendants of the object it is defined on.
Type: string.
Value description: Interpretation of the value is dependent on selected slr_storageProfile. It must represent the restriction to apply to the indicated sub part of the document.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: file, group, unit, <mrk>, sm, <pc> and sc.

section.title: slr_sizeRestriction
section.para: This string property specifies the size restriction to apply to the collection descendants of the element it is defined on.
Type: string.
Value description: Interpretation of the value is dependent on selected slr_generalProfile. It must represent the restriction to apply to the indicated sub part of the document.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: file, group, unit, mrk, sm, pc and sc.

section.title: slr_equivStorage
section.para: This string property provides a means to specify how much storage space an inline element will use in the native format. This size contribution is then added to the size contributed by the textual parts. This string property is only allowed on the ec element if that element has the isolated property set to "yes". Otherwise the property on the paired sc element also cover its partner ec element.
Type: string.
Value description: Interpretation of the value is dependent on selected slr_storageProfile. It must represent the equivalent storage size represented by the inline element.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: <pc>, sc, ec, ph.

section.title: slr_sizeInfo
section.para: This string property is used to associate profile specific information to inline elements so that size information can be decoupled from the native format or represented when the native data is not available in the JLIFF document. It can be used on both inline elements and structural elements to provide information on things like GUI dialog or control sizes, expected padding or margins to consider for size, what font is used for contained text and so on. This attribute is only allowed on the ec element if that element has the isolated attribute set to "yes". Otherwise the string property on the paired sc element also cover its partner ec element.

Value description: Interpretation of the value is dependent on selected xlr_generalProfile. It must represent information related to how the object it is attached to contributes to the size of the text or entity in which it occurs or represents.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: file, group, unit, pc, sc, ec, and ph.

listitem.para: This string property must not be specified if and only if slr_sizeInfoRef is used. They must not be specified at the same time.

section.title: slr_sizeInfoRef
section.para: This string property is used to point to data that provide the same function as the skr_sizeInfo string property does, but with the data stored outside the inline content of the JLIFF segment. This attribute is only allowed on the ec element if that element has the isolated attribute set to "yes". Otherwise the string property on the paired sc element also cover its partner ec element.
Type: string.

Value description: NMTOKEN: a string matching the pattern [-._:A-Za-z0-9]+, a reference to data that provide the same information that could be otherwise put in a slr_sizeInfo string property. The reference must point to an object in a slr_data object that is a sibling to the object this string property is attached to or a sibling to one of its ancestors.
Default value: undefined.
Used in: file, group, unit, pc, sc, ec, and ph,

listitem.para: This string property must not be specified if and only if slr_sizeInfo is used. They must not be specified at the same time.

section.title: General restriction profile ”xliff:codepoints”
section.para: This profile implements a simple string length restriction based on the number of Unicode code points. It is optional to specify if normalization is to be applied using the <normalization> element and the general attribute. This profile makes use of the following attributes from this module:

section.title: sizeRestriction
section.para: The value of this attribute holds the ”maximum” or ”minimum and maximum” size of the string. Either size must be an integer. The maximum size may also be ’*’ to denote that there is no maximum restriction. If only a maximum is specified it is implied that the minimum is 0 (empty string). The format of the value is the optional minimum size and a coma followed by a maximum size (”[minsize,]maxsize”). The default value is ’*’ which evaluates to a string with unbounded size.

section.title: sizeInfo
section.para: The value of this attribute is an integer representing how many code points the element it is set on is considered to contribute to the total size. If empty, the default for all elements is 0.

section.title: Storage restriction profiles ”xliff:utf8”, ”xliff:utf16” and ”xliff:utf32”
section.para: These three profiles define the standard size restriction profiles for the common Unicode character encoding schemes. It is optional to specify if normalization is to be applied using the <normalization>element and the storage. All sizes are represented in 8bit bytes. The size of text for these profiles is the size of the text converted to the selected encoding without any byte order marks attached. The encodings are specified by the Unicode Consortium in chapter 2.5 of the Unicode Standard [Unicode].

row.entry: The number of 8bit bytes needed to represent the string encoded as UTF-8 as specified by the Unicode consortium.
The number of 8bit bytes needed to represent the string encoded as UTF-16 as specified by the Unicode consortium.
The number of 8bit bytes needed to represent the string encoded as UTF-32 as specified by the Unicode consortium.

section.para: These profiles make use of the following attributes from this module:

section.title: storageRestriction
section.para: The value of this attribute holds the ”maximum” or ”minimum and maximum” size of the string. Either size must be an integer. The maximum size may also be ’*’ to denote that there is no maximum restriction. If only a maximum is specified it is implied that the minimum is 0 (empty string). The format of the value is the optional minimum size and a coma followed by a maximum size (”[minsize,]maxsize”). The default value is ’*’ which evaluates to a string with unbounded size.

section.title: equivStorage
section.para: The value of this attribute is an integer representing how many bytes the element it is set on is considered to contribute to the total size. If empty the default is 0. The <cp> is always converted to its representation in the profiles encoding and the size of that representation is used as the size contributed by the <cp>.

section.title: Third party profiles
section.para: The general structure of this module together with the extensibility mechanisms provided has been designed with the goal to cater for all practically thinkable size restriction schemes. For example, to represent two dimensional data, a profile can adopt a coordinate style for the values of the general restriction attributes. For instance {x,y} to represent width and height, or {{x1,y1},{x2,y2}} to represent a bounding box. It is also possible to embed information necessary to drive for instance a display simulator and attach that data to text in order to be able to perform device specific checking. Providing font information and checking glyph based general size are other feasible options.

section.title: Conformance
section.para: To claim conformance to the XLIFF size and length restriction module an Agent must meet the following criteria:

listitem.para: must be compliant with the schema of the XLIFF Core specification and its extensions provided in this module.
must follow all processing requirements set forth in this module specification regarding the general use of elements and attributes.
must support all standard profiles with normalization set to none.
should support all standard profiles with all modes of normalization.
may support additional third party profiles for storage or general restrictions.
must provide at least one of the following:
add size and length restriction information to an XLIFF Document
if it supports the profile(s) specified in the XLIFF Document it must provide a way to check if the size and length restrictions in the document are met according to the profile(s) requirements.

section.title: Example
section.para:
A short example on how this module can be used is provided here with inline XML comments explaining the usage of the module features.
<xliff version="2.0" srcLang="en-us" xmlns="urn:oasis:names:tc:xliff:document:2.0" xmlns:slr="urn:oasis:names:tc:xliff:sizerestriction:2.0"> <file id="f1"> <slr:profiles generalProfile="xliff:codepoints" storageProfile="xliff:utf8"> <!-- Select standard UTF-8 storage encoding and standard codepoint size restriction both with NFC normalization--> <slr:normalization general="nfc" storage="nfc" /> </slr:profiles> <!-- The group should not require more than 255 bytes of storage And have at most 90 codepoints. Note that the sum of the unit sizes are larger than this the total content of the group must still be at most 90 codepoints. --> <group id="g1" slr:storageRestriction="255" slr:sizeRestriction="90"> <!-- This unit must not contain more than 60 code points --> <unit id="u1" slr:sizeRestriction="60"> <segment> <!-- The spanning <pc> element require 7 bytes of storage in the native format. Its content must not have more than 25 codepoints --> <source>This is a small <pc equivStorage="7" slr:sizeRestriction="25">size restriction</pc> example. </source> </segment> </unit> <!-- This unit must not have more than 35 codepoints --> <unit id="u2" slr:sizeRestriction="35"> <segment> <source>With a group structure.</source> </segment> </unit> </group> </file> </xliff>

section.title: Introduction
section.para: This module defines a specific set of validation rules that can be applied to target text both globally and locally. Further constraints can be defined that allow rules to be applied to target text based on conditions in the source text or disabled to override a global scope.

section.title: Module Namespace and Validation Artifacts
section.para: The namespace for the Validation module is: urn:oasis:names:tc:xliff:validation:2.0

Schema and Schematron for this module are available at http://docs.oasis-open.org/xliff-omos/jliff/v1.0/wd01/schemas/validation.xsd and http://docs.oasis-open.org/xliff-omos/jliff/v1.0/wd01/schemas/validation.sch.

section.title: Module Fragment Identification Prefix
section.para: The fragment identification prefix for the Validation module is: val

section.title: Module Elements
section.para: The elements defined in the Validation module are: <validation> and <rule>.

section.title: Tree Structure
section.para: Legend:

simplelist.member: + = one or more

section.programlisting: <validation> | +---<rule> +

section.title: val_validation
section.para: Array containing a list of rules and constraints to apply to the target text of the enclosing object.
Type: non-empty array of val_ruleobjects.

simplelist.member: - One or more <rule> elements.
- attributes from other namespaces, optional

listitem.para: When the "val_validation" array property occurs at the file level, rules must be applied to all target objects within the scope of that file object, except where overrides are specified at the group or unit level.

When "val_validation" array propertyoccurs at the group level, rules must be applied to all target objects within the scope of that group, except where overrides are specified in a nested group object, or at the unit level.
When "val_validation" array propertyoccurs at the unit level, rules must be applied to all target objects within the scope of that unit.

section.title: anonymous val_rule object
section.para: A specific rule and constraint to apply to the target text of the enclosing element.
Type: object.

simplelist.member: - This element is always empty.
- val_validation array
- "isPresent", a val_isPresent string, optional
- "occurs", a val_occurs integer larger or equal to 1, optional
- "isNotPresent", a val_isNotPresent string with value "yes" or "no", optional
- "startsWith", a val_startsWith string, optional
- "endsWith", a val_endsWith string, optional
- "existsInSource", a val_existsInSource string with value "yes" or "no", optional
- "caseSentitive", a val_caseSensitive string with value "yes" or "no", optional
- "normalization", a val_normalization string with value "none", "nfc" or "nfd", optional
- "disabled", a val_disabled string with value "yes" or "no", optional
- attributes from other namespaces, optional

listitem.para:
Exactly one of the following properties:
"isPresent", a val_isPresent string
"isNotPresent", a val_isNotPresent string
"startsWith", a val_startsWith string
"endsWith", a val_endsWith string
a custom rule defined by attributes from any namespace
is required in any one val_rule objects.
Writers may create and add new val_rule objects, provided that the new rules do not contradict rules already present.
Modifiers must not change properties defined in this module that are already present in any val_rule object.
Modifiers must not remove either val_rule objects or their properties defined in this module.

section.title: Module Attributes
section.para: The attributes defined in the Validation module are: isPresent, occurs, isNotPresent, startsWith, endsWith, existsInSource, caseSensitive, normalization, and disabled.

section.title: val_isPresent
section.para: This rule property specifies that a string must be present in the target text at least once.
For example, the following is valid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule isPresent="online" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose an option in the online store.</source> <target>Escolha uma opção na loja online.</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles" [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "isPresent": "online" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose an option in the online store." } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção na loja online." } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Whereas the following is invalid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule isPresent="loja" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose an option in the online store.</source> <target>Escolha uma opção na online store.</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "isPresent": "loja" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose an option in the online store." } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção na online store." } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Other rule properties can be combined with isPresent to produce the following results:

simplelist.member: "isPresent": ”loja” - loja is found in the target text at least once.
"isPresent": ”loja”, "occurs": 1 - loja is found in the target text exactly once.
"isPresent": ”loja”, "existsInSource": ”yes” - loja is found in both source and target text the same number of times.
"isPresent": ”loja”, "existsInSource": ”yes”, "occurs": 1 - loja is found in both source and target text and occurs in target text exactly once.

section.para: Type: string.
Value description: text.
Default value: undefined.

section.title: val_occurs
section.para: This rule property is used with the val_isPresent rule property to specify the exact number of times a string must be present in the target text. When this rule property is not used, then the string must be present in the target text at least once.
For example, the following is valid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule isPresent="loja" occurs="2" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose a store option in the online store.</source> <target>Escolha uma opção de loja na loja online.</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "isPresent": "loja", "occurs": 2 ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose a store option in the online store." } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção de loja na loja online." } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Whereas the following is invalid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule isPresent="loja" occurs="2" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose a store option in the online store.</source> <target>Escolha uma opção de loja na online store.</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "isPresent": "loja", "occurs": 2 ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose a store option in the online store." } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção de loja na online store." } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Type: string.
Value description: an integer value of 1 or greater.
Default value: undefined.

section.title: val_isNotPresent
section.para: This rule property specifies that a string must not be present in the target text.
For example, the following is valid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule isNotPresent="store" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose an option in the online store.</source> <target>Escolha uma opção na loja online.</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "isNotPresent": "store" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose an option in the online store." } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção na loja online." } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Whereas the following is invalid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule isNotPresent="store" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose an option in the online store.</source> <target>Escolha uma opção na online store.</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "isNotPresent": "store" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose an option in the online store." } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção na online store." } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Type: string.
Value description: text.
Default value: undefined.

section.title: val_startsWith
section.para: This rule property specifies that a string must start with a specific value.
For example, the following is valid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule startsWith="*" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>*Choose an option in the online store.</source> <target>*Escolha uma opção na loja online.</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "startsWith": "*" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "*Choose an option in the online store." } ], "target": [ { "text": "*Escolha uma opção na loja online." } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Whereas the following is invalid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule startsWith="*" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>*Choose an option in the online store.</source> <target>Escolha uma opção na loja online.</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "startsWith": "*" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "*Choose an option in the online store." } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção na loja online." } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Type: string.
Value description: text.
Default value: undefined.

section.title: val_endsWith
section.para: This rule property specifies that a string must end with a specific value.
For example, the following is valid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule endsWith=":" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose an option in the online store:</source> <target>Escolha uma opção na loja online:</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "endsWith": ":" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose an option in the online store:" } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção na loja online:" } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Whereas the following is invalid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule endsWith=":" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose an option in the online store:</source> <target>Escolha uma opção na online store.</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "endsWith": ":" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose an option in the online store:" } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção na online store." } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Type: string.
Value description: text.
Default value: undefined.

section.title: val_existsInSource
section.para: When this rule property is used with another rule and is set to "yes", it specifies that for the rule to succeed, the condition must be satisfied in both source and target text. This rule property is valid only when used with one of the following rule properties: val_isPresent, val_startsWith, or val_endsWith.
When property "existsInSource" is set to "no", it will have no impact on execution of rules, except for overriding rules where property "existsInSource" is set to "yes" on a higher level.
For example, the following are valid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule endsWith=":" existsInSource="yes" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose an option in the online store:</source> <target>Escolha uma opção na loja online:</target> </segment> </unit> ... <unit id="2"> <val:validation> <val:rule endsWith=":" existsInSource="no" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose an option in the online store.</source> <target>Escolha uma opção na loja online:</target> </segment> </unit> "subfiles": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "endsWith": ":", "existsInSource": "yes" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose an option in the online store:" } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção na loja online:" } ], } ] } ... { "id": "2", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "endsWith": ":", "existsInSource": "no" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose an option in the online store:" } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção na loja online:" } ], } ] } ]
section.para: Whereas the following is invalid:
section.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <val:validation> <val:rule endsWith=":" existsInSource="yes" /> </val:validation> <segment id="1"> <source>Choose an option in the online store.</source> <target>Escolha uma opção na loja online:</target> </segment> </unit> { "id": "1", "kind": "unit", "val_validation": [ "endsWith": ":", "existsInSource": "yes" ], "subunits": [ { "id": "1", "kind": "segment", "source": [ { "text": "Choose an option in the online store:" } ], "target": [ { "text": "Escolha uma opção na loja online:" } ], } ] }
section.para: Type: string.
Value description: "yes" or "no".
Default value: "no".

listitem.para:
When existsInSource is specified, exactly one of
"isPresent", a val_isPresent string
"startsWith", a val_startsWith string
"endsWith", a val_endsWith string
is required in the same val_rule object.

section.title: val_caseSensitive
section.para: This rule property specifies whether the test defined within that rule is case sensitive or not.
Type: string.
Value description: "yes" if the test is case sensitive, "no" if the test is case insensitive.
Default value: "yes".

section.title: val_normalization
section.para: This rule property specifies the normalization type to apply when validating a rule. Only the normalization forms C and D as specified in [UAX #15].
Type: string.
Value description: the allowed values are listed in the table below along with their corresponding types of normalization to be applied.

row.entry: Normalization Form C must be used.
Normalization Form D must be used.

section.para: Default value: "nfc".

section.title: val_disabled
section.para: This rule property determines whether a rule must or must not be applied within the scope of its enclosing object. For example, a rule defined at the file level can be disabled at the unit level.
This property is provided to allow for overriding execution of rules set at higher levels, see val_validation.
In the following example, the isNotPresent rule is applied in its entirety to the first unit, but not to the second.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: This module defines Inline Annotations (normative usage descriptions for attributes on inline annotation markers), attributes and elements that are needed to map [ITS] data categories using only XLIFF-defined elements and attributes. The module also defines an external rules file to be used by generic ITS processors working with XLIFF Documents. This module only defines attributes and annotations that are not available through XLIFF Core or other Modules. This module specification also contains normative provisions for mapping of [ITS] data categories and features that are available via XLIFF Core and other modules (ITS data categories available through XLIFF Core and other Modules and ITS data categories that have a partial overlap with XLIFF features) or other Modules outside of the ITS Module (ITS data categories that have a partial overlap with XLIFF features). Finally an overview of data categories is provided where the information is or can be fully expressed by Extraction behavior and therefore those categories or their parts (sub-categories) cannot be represented as metadata within XLIFF Documents (ITS data categories that do not represent metadata after Extraction of content into XLIFF).

note.para: This module specification chiefly describes how the [ITS] data categories need to be expressed within XLIFF Documents. Some metadata categories are typically Extracted from native source formats, others would be first injected into XLIFF Documents by Enriching Agents and might be useful or not in the target content after Merging back to the native format in the target natural language. For all metadata categories that can be encoded within XLIFF Documents, there is an important XLIFF specific distinction between structural and inline elements in XLIFF. Some categories can only be expressed inline in XLIFF Documents. Others can be also expressed on structural markup levels; in such a case, inheritance (or not) from the XLIFF structural levels is important. Nevertheless, even the inline only metadata categories can be in scope of ITS Tools Referencing that can be set on structural levels and possible inheritance of relevant its:annotatorsRef values needs to be always checked by implementers.

warning.para: There is an important scope difference between attributes from the namespace https://www.w3.org/2005/11/its/ as implemented in XLIFF Documents and as defined in the [ITS] specification itself. This affects all ITS attributes that can be used on inline spans. In XLIFF, spans delimited by the well-formed <mrk> are always equivalent and interchangeable with pseudo-spans delimited by <sm/> / <em/> pairs. In many cases delimiting the needed spans by <mrk> is impossible due to overlap with other well-formed spans, while delimiting of inline spans with <sm/> / <em/> pairs is always possible and often preferable as it allows the spans to persist even through a change of segmentation.

However, [ITS] doesn't define a pseudo-span mechanism and thus generic ITS Processors cannot parse pseudo-spans. ITS processors will generally identify ITS attributes or their mappings from XLIFF specific namespaces on the <sm/> markers, but they will consider their scope to be the empty marker itself, whereas the true scope of all attributes on such markers within XLIFF Documents is between the start marker <sm id="1"/> and it's corresponding end marker <em startRef="1"/>.

Implementers who wish to better access [ITS] metadata categories information within XLIFF Documents can easily implement an additional capability in their ITS Processors to detect spans like this one <sm id="1"/>span of text<em startRef="1"/> without going into any more XLIFF specific features and becoming full fledged XLIFF Agents.

section.title: Module Namespace and Validation Artifacts
section.para: The namespaces for the ITS module are: https://www.w3.org/2005/11/its/ and urn:oasis:names:tc:xliff:itsm:2.1.

Schemas and Schematron for this module are available at http://docs.oasis-open.org/xliff-omos/jliff/v1.0/wd01/schemas/its.xsd, http://docs.oasis-open.org/xliff-omos/jliff/v1.0/wd01/schemas/itsm.xsd, and http://docs.oasis-open.org/xliff-omos/jliff/v1.0/wd01/schemas/its.sch.

note.para: Although setting and usage of prefixes for namespaces in XML is arbitrary, we are using its: for the https://www.w3.org/2005/11/its/ namespace and itsm: for the urn:oasis:names:tc:xliff:itsm:2.1 namespace throughout this specification.

section.title: Module Fragment Identification Prefix
section.para: The fragment identification prefix for the ITS module is: its.

note.para: Although this module has to use two different XML namespace prefixes it uses only one fragment identification and authority prefix which is its.

section.title: Conformance to the ITS Module Specification

note.para: Some ITS data categories like Translate are supported natively by XLIFF. Other data categories are not supported by XLIFF because they are focusing on source content and not XLIFF content. The below conformance statement is only relevant for data categories for which the usage in XLIFF 2.1 is normatively defined in this XLIFF 2.1 ITS Module. Like in the [ITS] 2.0 specification, there is no interrelation between data categories.

listitem.para: Conformant ITS Processors must be able to use the external global rules included in the module's Schematron file http://docs.oasis-open.org/xliff-omos/jliff/v1.0/wd01/schemas/its.sch and compute ITS data categories encoded in XLIFF Documents as per [ITS] Conformance clauses 2-1, 2-2, 2-3, and 2-4.

In cases where any of the above specified global rules identifies an empty <sm> element, conformant ITS Processors should be able identify the closing <em> marker and process the relevant ITS data category as applied on the span delimited by those corresponding empty markers.

Conformant Agents must be XLIFF Conformant in the sense of JLIFF Application Conformance and also implement at least one [ITS] data category defined in the section ITS data categories defined in the ITS Module of this ITS Module or provide full support for at least one of the [ITS] custom annotations (ITS Mapping Annotations) specified in the Section ITS data categories that have a partial overlap with XLIFF features.
In particular:

Conformant Extractors must be capable of Extracting at least one of the above specified ITS data categories from a source format and encode it in a resulting conformant XLIFF Document with ITS Module based metadata.
Conformant Enrichers must be capable of Enriching XLIFF Documents with at least one of the above specified ITS data categories.
Conformant Modifiers must be capable of updating at least one of the above specified ITS data categories according to its own Constraints and Processing Requirements as specified in the ITS Module.

Conformant Mergers must be capable of Merging metadata of at least one of the above specified ITS data categories back to the respective native format (with full knowledge of the Extraction mechanism) in the target natural language.

section.title: ITS Tools Referencing
section.para: [ITS] Tools Annotation mechanism provides a way to record tools that produced [ITS] metadata.

warning.para: This mechanism is reserved for recording producers of ITS metadata. General provenance information can be recorded using the Provenance data category mapping defined in this Module. If an Agent records the revision history of previous versions, they need do this using the Change Tracking Module, possibly extended with ITS Module Provenance metadata.

note.para: The ITS Tools Referencing mechanism has to be always used with the MT Confidence data category. The Terminology and Text Analysis metadata categories have to use ITS Tools Referencing conditionally, i.e. whenever they specify its:termConfidence or its:taConfidence respectively.

With all other [ITS] metadata categories, there is no express need to use the ITS Tools Referencing mechanism. It is nevertheless advised that the relevant ITS Tooling metadata is Extracted where available and Modified when the relevant ITS metadata category information changes during the XLIFF Document processing. Finally, all conformant Agents and ITS Processors need to be able to compute the ITS Tools Referencing information in case this has been provided by other conformant Agents earlier in the workflow as per the ITS Module Conformance section.

listitem.para: Writers must use the attribute its:annotatorsRef to express the information provided through the [ITS] Tools Annotation mechanism in XLIFF Documents.

section.title: ITS Tools Annotation
section.para: This is used to express the [ITS] Tools Annotation mechanism on inline markers.
Usage:

listitem.para: The id attribute is required.
The its:annotatorsRef attribute is required.
The type attribute is optional and set to its:generic.
The translate attribute is optional.

section.title: ITS data categories defined in the ITS Module
section.para: The following [ITS] data categories are fully specified within this module:

section.title: Allowed Characters
section.para: Used to specify the characters that are permitted in a given piece of content. See [ITS] Allowed Characters for further details.

listitem.para: Writers must use the ITS Allowed Characters Annotation to express the [ITS] Allowed Characters data category in XLIFF Documents.
For both structural and inline elements, use <mrk> or an <sm/> / <em/> pair with the following attribute: its:allowedCharacters.
See the ITS Allowed Characters Annotation for the normative usage description of this attribute and the following sections for further details on structural and inline elements.

section.title: Structural Elements
section.para: If a structural element of the original document has a Allowed Characters annotation, it is recommended to represent that annotation using a <mrk> element that encloses the whole content of the <source> element.

See the ITS Domain Annotation for the normative usage description on inline markers.

section.para: This is used to express inline the [ITS] Domain data category.

section.title: Locale Filter
section.para: Expresses that a node is only applicable to certain locales. See [ITS] Locale Filter for further details.

This section describes how the Locale Filter information can be represented inline in XLIFF Documents if necessary. However, it is preferable that this data category is fully consumed by Extaction/Merge behavior as recommended in the section on ITS metadata categories that are not explicitly represented in XLIFF Documents.

listitem.para: Writers must use the ITS Locale Filter Annotation to express the [ITS] Locale Filter data category in XLIFF Documents that don't have set the target locale.
Writers must use the XLIFF Core Translate Annotation to express the [ITS] Locale Filter data category in XLIFF Documents with the target locale set.
Modifiers must remove the ITS Locale Filter Annotation and replace it with the XLIFF Core Translate Annotation when setting the trgLang or when receiving an XLIFF Documents with trgLang set.

section.para: Core only Modifiers might have invalidated the ITS Locale Filter Annotation by setting the trgLang. Although, this is addressed by the above PR, [ITS] Locale Filter capable Modifiers are strongly advised to better set the trgLang as soon as known and perform the above specified annotations' transformation rather than to assume that other tools downstream will be capable of interpreting the [ITS] Locale Filter metadata when setting the target locale. For both structural and inline elements, use <mrk> or an <sm/> / <em/> pair with the following attributes: its:localeFilterList and its:localeFilterType.
See the ITS Locale Filter Annotation for the normative usage description of those attributes and the following sections for further details on structural and inline elements.

section.title: Structural Elements
section.para: When the target locale in XLIFF is undefined, the locale filter data category may be Extracted using the ITS Locale Filter Annotation.

Text A

Text B

section.para: This is used to fully map to and from the [ITS] Locale Filter data category.
Usage:

The type attribute is optional and set to its:generic.
The its:localeFilterType attribute is optional and used to map to and from the [ITS] defined localeFilterList attribute.

section.title: Localization Quality Issue
section.para: Expresses information related to localization quality assessment tasks in the form of highlighted issues. See [ITS] Localization Quality Issue for more details.

listitem.para: Writers must use the ITS Localization Quality Issue Annotation to express the [ITS] Localization Quality Issue data category in XLIFF Documents.

section.title: Structural Elements
section.para: Localization Quality Issue is not to be used at structural levels. If a structural element of the original document has [ITS] Localization Quality Issue information associated, it must be anyway Extracted using the ITS Localization Quality Issue Annotation.

note.para: If human reviewers or other QA agents (Enriching Agents from the XLIFF specification point of view), need to insert general comments pertaining to whole structural elements such as paragraphs, sections, or files rather than to specific inline portions of source or target content, the Localization Note data category is more suitable.

section.title: Inline Elements
section.para: Use <mrk> or an <sm/> / <em/> pair with the attributes: its:locQualityIssueComment, its:locQualityIssueEnabled, its:locQualityIssueProfileRef, its:locQualityIssuesRef, its:locQualityIssueSeverity, and its:locQualityIssueType.
See the ITS Localization Quality Issue Annotation for the normative usage description of those attributes.

Because the same or overlapping spans of source or target text can be associated with more than one quality issue, this category provides its own elements that are to be used at the unit level as an alternative to the inline only annotations, especially in cases the inline only annotations would not be expressive enough to capture the issues to be reported. If more than one quality issue applies to the same content the particulars of those issues need to be stored in standoff annotations.
For specifics of the standoff annotation, see the <locQualityIssue> and <locQualityIssues> elements and the attributes its:locQualityIssuesRef and id.

section.title: ITS Localization Quality Issue Annotation
section.para: This is used to fully map to and from the [ITS] Localization Quality Issue data category.
Usage:

listitem.para: The id attribute is required.
The type attribute is optional and set to its:generic.
Exactly one of the following must be set:
its:locQualityIssuesRef.

itemizedlist.para: At least one of the following must be set:

listitem.para: its:locQualityIssueType,
its:locQualityIssueComment.
The translate attribute is optional.
The following attributes must not be set if and only if its:locQualityIssuesRef is declared, otherwise all of the following are optional:
its:locQualityIssueSeverity,
its:locQualityIssueProfileRef, and
its:locQualityIssueEnabled.

warning.para: Usage of the its:locQualityIssuesRef attribute implies usage of Localization Quality Issue standoff elements. See <locQualityIssues> and <locQualityIssue> for related Constraints and Processing Requirements.

example.title: Enriching XLIFF Documents with Localization Quality Issue Annotations
example.programlisting: <unit id="1"> <segment> <source>This is the content</source> <target><mrk id="m1" type="its:generic" its:locQualityIssueType="misspelling" its:locQualityIssueComment="'c'es' is unknown. Could be 'c'est'" its:locQualityIssueSeverity="50">c'es</mrk> le contenu</target> </segment> </unit>

<unit id="1"> <its:locQualityIssues xml:id="lqi1"> <its:locQualityIssue locQualityIssueType="misspelling" locQualityIssueComment="'c'es' is unknown. Could be 'c'est'" locQualityIssueSeverity="50" /> <its:locQualityIssue locQualityIssueType="grammar" locQualityIssueComment="Sentence is not capitalized" locQualityIssueSeverity="30" /> </its:locQualityIssues> <segment> <source>This is the content</source> <target><mrk id="m1" type="its:generic" its:locQualityIssuesRef="lqi1">c'es le contenu</mrk></target> </segment> </unit>
example.para: The annotatorsRef attribute inherits information in the document tree. The attribute annotatorsRef does not relate to standoff information. This is exemplified below. The <mrk id="m1"> element has the annotatorsRef information - via tool2 - expressed at the target element. The tool1 annotatorsRef expressed at the unit element does not influence that interpretation and the standoff information in <locQualityIssues>.
example.programlisting: <unit id="1" its:annotatorsRef="localization-quality-issue|tool1"> <its:locQualityIssues xml:id="lqi1"> <its:locQualityIssue locQualityIssueType="misspelling" locQualityIssueComment="'c'es' is unknown. Could be 'c'est'" locQualityIssueSeverity="50" /> <its:locQualityIssue locQualityIssueType="grammar" locQualityIssueComment="Sentence is not capitalized" locQualityIssueSeverity="30" /> </its:locQualityIssues> <segment > <source>This is the content</source> <target its:annotatorsRef="localization-quality-issue|tool2"><mrk id="m1" type="its:generic" its:locQualityIssuesRef="lqi1">c'es le contenu</mrk></target> </segment> </unit>

section.title: Localization Quality Rating
section.para: Expresses results of localization quality assessment in the form of aggreagated ratings, either as scores or as voting results. See [ITS] Localization Quality Rating for more details.

listitem.para: Writers must use the ITS Localization Quality Rating Annotation to express the [ITS] Localization Quality Rating data category on inline spans within XLIFF Documents.

section.para: Localization Quality Rating is usually expressed at structural levels as it normally expresses summary rating (scoring or voting) information for larger chunks of text. Rating information inherits to lower level elements but can be overridden at lower levels.
Attributes may be set on XLIFF Core structural elements, so that the following advanced Constraints are met.

listitem.para: Exactly one of the following must be set or inherited:
its:locQualityRatingScore:
its:locQualityRatingScoreThreshold may be set or inherited if and only if its:locQualityRatingScore is set.
its:locQualityRatingVote:
its:locQualityRatingVoteThreshold may be set or inherited if and only if its:locQualityRatingVote is set or inherited.
The its:locQualityRatingProfileRef attribute is optional.

section.title: Inline Elements
section.para:
Use <mrk> or an <sm/> / <em/> pair with the following attributes:
its:locQualityRatingProfileRef,
its:locQualityRatingScore,
its:locQualityRatingScoreThreshold,
its:locQualityRatingVote,
its:locQualityRatingVoteThreshold.
See the ITS Localization Quality Rating Annotation for the normative usage description of those attributes inline.

section.title: ITS Localization Quality Rating Annotation
section.para: This is used to fully map to and from the [ITS] Localization Quality Rating data category on inline elements.
Usage:

listitem.para: The id attribute is required.
The type attribute is optional and set to its:generic.
Exactly one of the following must be set:
its:locQualityRatingScore:
its:locQualityRatingScoreThreshold may be set or inherited if and only if its:locQualityRatingScore is set.
its:locQualityRatingVote:
